What is learning?¶

Learning¶

  • From Merriam-Webster:
    1. The act or experience of one that learns.
    2. Knowledge or skill acquired by instruction or study.
    3. Modification of a behavioral tendency by experience (such as exposure to conditioning.)

Learning in this course¶




Using experience to improve future performance:

  • Experience = Data
  • Future = Data not seen before
  • Performance = Error function or loss function

What is statistical learning?¶

From ISLR:

Statistical learning refers to a vast set of tools for understanding data. These tools can be classified as supervised or unsupervised. Broadly speaking, supervised statistical learning involves building a statistical model for predicting, or estimating, an output based on one or more inputs. With unsupervised statistical learning, there are inputs but no supervising output; nevertheless we can learn relationships and structure from such data.

Terminology¶

  • What we measure: features (input variables, predictors, or independent variables.)

  • What we want to predict or associate with what we measure: output (label, response, dependent variable.)

  • In the case of unsupervised learning, we do not have outputs.

  • We will focus on supervised learning first.

Terminology (2)¶

  • What we measure: features

  • What we want to predict or associate with what we measure: output

  • Identify the features and outputs in the following examples:

    • Predict the price of a stock in 6 months from now, on the basis of company performance measures and economic data.
    • Predict whether a patient, hospitalized due to a heart attack, will have a second heart attack. The prediction is to be based on demographic, diet and clinical measurements for that patient.
    • Identify the numbers in a handwritten ZIP code, from a digitized image.
    • Predict the longitude and latitude of a car based on GPS measurements, accelerometer, and gyroscope.
    • Predict the hash tags of a tweet based on its text.

Example: Diabetes dataset¶


  • Ten baseline variables including age, sex, body mass index, average blood pressure, and six blood serum measurements were obtained for each of nn = 442 diabetes patients, as well as the response of interest, a quantitative measure of disease progression one year after baseline.
  • What we might want to "learn" from this dataset?

A statistical perspective on learning¶

  • We wish to learn something from the data DD.
  • Statistical learning means that the data have been generated by some unknown random process:
    x,y∼p()x,y∼p()
  • This reads "x,yx,y are sampled according to the probability distribution p(⋅)p(⋅)."
  • We wish to estimate the unknown pp from such data.

Quick probability review¶


  • There is a **sample space** of possible events.
  • An event has a **probability** of happening (instead of a certainty).
  • Probability theory develops ways of estimating probabilities of events.

Quick probability review (2)¶


  • **Probability of an event** AA is denoted by p(A)p(A)
  • **Conditional probability** selects one subset of the sample space p(x∣y)=p(x,y)/p(y)p(x∣y)=p(x,y)/p(y)
  • **Independence of events**: if x1x1 and x2x2 are independent events then p(x1,x2)=p(x1)p(x2)p(x1,x2)=p(x1)p(x2)

How bad are we at probabilities?¶

  • You go to a friend's house and you know that she has two children.
  • Suddenly, a girl runs between the two of you, and your friend says "she is my daughter."
  • What is the probability that the other child is also a girl?

Hint: Conditioning selects one subset of the sample space

p(x∣y)=p(x,y)/p(y)p(x∣y)=p(x,y)/p(y)

A statistical perspective on learning¶

  • Statistical learning refers to a set of approaches for estimating ff assuming some noise added into the system, which cannot be predicted from xx.


Why we estimate ff ?¶

  • Broadly speaking, we want to estimate ff to make predictions or inference, or both.
  • Prediction for a new data point never seen before: Y=f(X)Y=f(X)
  • E.g., for the diabetes case, we might want to predict disease progression based on the BMI of a patient.

Why we estimate ff ? (2)¶


  • Assuming that there is a function such that
    y=f(x)+ϵy=f(x)+ϵ
  • We wish to minimize some loss function using our estimation
    Y^=f^(X)Y^=f^(X)
  • How small can we get our loss function?

Why we estimate ff ? (3)¶

  • There is always reducible error and irreducible error.

  • Squared error:

    E[(Y−Y^)2]=E[(f(X)+ϵ−f^(X))2]=E[(f(X)−f^(X))2+2(f(X)−f^(X))ϵ+ϵ2]=E[(f(X)−f^(X))2]+E[2(f(X)−f^(X))ϵ]0+E[ϵ2]=E[(f(X)−f^(X))2]+E[ϵ2]E[(Y−Y^)2]=E[(f(X)+ϵ−f^(X))2]=E[(f(X)−f^(X))2+2(f(X)−f^(X))ϵ+ϵ2]=E[(f(X)−f^(X))2]+E[2(f(X)−f^(X))ϵ]⏞0+E[ϵ2]=E[(f(X)−f^(X))2]+E[ϵ2]

  • E[(f(X)−f^(X))2]E[(f(X)−f^(X))2] is reducible variance.

  • E[ϵ2]E[ϵ2] is irreducible variance.

Why we estimate ff ? (4)¶

  • Inference: sometimes we want to understand ff (look inside)

    • Which predictors are associated with YY? e.g., do we need to include gender in the prediction of blood pressure?

    • Relationship between YY and each XX. e.g., blood pressure is higher for older people?

    • Is the relationship between YY and XX appropriately captured by the model? Is the linear relationship enough?

How do we estimate ff ?¶

  • We estimate using training data. For notation, we will assume that we have nn training points. xijxij is the value of variable jj for data point ii, and yiyi is the independent variable for that data point.

  • Parametric methods

    1. Define the form of ff (e.g., linear model.)
    2. Use a procedure to fit or train the model.

  • Nonparametric methods

    • These methods don’t make assumptions about ff.
    • Informally, they try to get as close as possible to the training data but not too close.
    • In general, the more data, the better the fit, but the harder to intepret.

How do we estimate ff ? (2)¶

  • Sometimes, the probability distribution that generated the data is known or assumed to be known, except for a set of parameters describing it.

x,y∼p(θ)x,y∼p(θ)

  • We need to infer θθ

Two views on statistical learning¶

  • Bayesian statistics: use prior knowledge about the phenomenon and then combine evidence with that prior knowledge.

Mathematically, use prior over unknown parameters (p(θ)p(θ)) and the likelihood of the data given a parameter value (p(x,y∣θ)p(x,y∣θ)). Use Baye's Theorem to infer the data generating distribution.

θ^∼p(θ∣x,y)=p(x,y∣θ)p(θ)p(x,y)θ^∼p(θ∣x,y)=p(x,y∣θ)p(θ)p(x,y)

Two views on statistical learning (2)¶

  • Frequentist statistics:

    • Defines an estimator for a parameter based on data.

    • It assumes a procedure where samples from the same data will be observed an infinite amount of time.

    • It uses the resampled estimated to build a distribution over estimations.

  • In this class, we will take a frequentist view:

    • We will use the Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE):

θ^=argmaxθp(y∣θ)θ^=arg⁡maxθp(y∣θ)

How do we perform MLE?¶

p(d1,d2,…,d442∣μ,σ)p(d1,d2,…,d442∣μ,σ)=∏i=14421σ2π−−√exp[−12σ2(di−μ)2]=(1σ2π−−√)442exp[−12σ2∑i=1442(di−μ)2]p(d1,d2,…,d442∣μ,σ)=∏i=14421σ2πexp⁡[−12σ2(di−μ)2]p(d1,d2,…,d442∣μ,σ)=(1σ2π)442exp⁡[−12σ2∑i=1442(di−μ)2]

  • Because pp is always positive, then we have the following property:

argmaxp(⋅)=argmaxlogp(⋅)arg⁡⁡max⁡p⁡(⋅)=arg⁡⁡max⁡log⁡p⁡(⋅)

How do we perform MLE? (2)¶

  • Let’s work through the math.

logp(d1,d2,…,d442∣μ,σ)=442log(1σ2π−−√)−12σ2∑i=1442(di−μ)2log⁡p(d1,d2,…,d442∣μ,σ)=442log⁡(1σ2π)−12σ2∑i=1442(di−μ)2

How do we perform MLE? (3)¶

  • Let’s rewrite to make it clear:

l(μ)=f1(σ)−f2(σ)∑i=1442(di−μ)2l(μ)=f1(σ)−f2(σ)∑i=1442(di−μ)2

How do we perform MLE? (4)¶

  • One way of finding maximum/minimum is to look at where the slopes are zero.


How do we perform MLE? (4)¶

  • Let’s rewrite to make it clear:
    $$\begin{align} \frac{dl(\mu)}{d\mu} &= 0 \ \frac{dl(\mu)}{d\mu}\left(f_1(\sigma) - f_2(\sigma)\sum (d_i-\mu)^2\right) &=0 \

  • f_2(\sigma)\sum \frac{d(d_i-\mu)^2}{d\mu} &= 0 \ \sum (d_i-\mu) &= 0 \ \sum d_i - \sum\mu &= 0 \ \sum d_i - n\mu &= 0 \ \frac{\sum d_i}{n} &= \mu \ \end{align}$$

  • Simply the empirical average! (Can you do the same with the standard deviation?)

Example: Diabetes dataset¶

  • The statistical estimation of the distribution that generates disease progression is the mean of the data!

  • Also, maximizing the likelihood under Gaussian assumption is equivalent to finding the minimum squared error between my estimation and the data.

  • Usually, algorithms try to minimize the negative loglikelihood (nLL), which is the same as maximizing the loglikelihood

Summary of disease progression estimation¶

  • We assume a statistical perspective to learn dp:

    • We assume that we have uncertainty in our process.

  • We define a model to make such prediction:

    • We define a Gaussian distribution around dp.

  • We use experience:

    • We use data to find an appropriate Gaussian distribution.

  • We define a loss function as performance:

    • We use the mean squared error to evaluate performance (any problems with this?)

More interesting statistical learning¶

  • Suppose there is a relationship:

    Y=f(X)+ϵY=f(X)+ϵ

    where XX is a set of independent variables and YY is an output variable, and ϵϵ is some noise (e.g., unobserved phenomena, variability of subjects) with mean zero.

  • Given that ϵϵ is a random variable, then the relationship is stochastic:
    p(Y∣X)∼N(f(X),σϵ)p(Y∣X)∼N(f(X),σϵ)

Parametric method: linear regression¶

  • Linear regression assumes a linear relationship between XX and YY plus some noise:

Y=Xβ+ϵY=Xβ+ϵ

  • The noise (ϵϵ) is assumed to be Gaussian.

  • Therefore, we find the parameters (ββ) by minimizing the squared error (or equivalently, maximizing the likelihood.)

Example: predicting progression based on BMI¶

  • Predict disease progression based on the BMI of a patient.

  • Prediction:

    Model: Y=β0+bmiβ1+ϵY=β0+bmiβ1+ϵ

  • Same as before, we want to find best β0β0 and β1β1 so as to maximize (*) or minimize the squared error:
    l(β0,β1)=∑(yi−μi)2l(β0,β1)=∑(yi−μi)2

Nonparametric method: Nearest neighbors¶


For a new data point X^X^ return the mean YY of the closest kk points in the training data:

  • Very simple to implement.
  • Needs lots of data to work well.
  • Hard to interpret.

Regression vs classification¶

  • When the variable we are trying to predict (YY) is quantitative, then we talk about regression.

  • When the variable is categorical (no easy comparison), then we talk about classification.

  • Examples of classification?

Classification: statistical formulation¶

  • In regression, we learn a continuous probability distribution such as Gaussian describing our outcome variable
  • In classification, we learn a discrete probability distribution for our outcome variable
  • This is because the variable yy takes on discrete values C1,C2,…,CkC1,C2,…,Ck

Example: two-class logistic regression for classification¶

  • One of the simplest models for classification
  • It makes use of the Bernoulli probability distribution
    p(y∣θ)=θy(1−θ)y−1p(y∣θ)=θy(1−θ)y−1
    where y∈{0,1}y∈{0,1} and represent two classes C1C1 and C2C2
  • Can you give examples of two-class classification problems?

Example: logistic regression¶

  • More specifically, we map each set of features xx into a value between 0 and 1 using the following transformation:
  • We first do a linear map of xx into zz:

z=b0+b1x1+⋯+bmxm=xTbz=b0+b1x1+⋯+bmxm=xTb

  • And then, we perform a non-linear transformation of zz

σ(z)=11+e−zσ(z)=11+e−z
which is called the sigmoid transform. The sigmoid is constrained between 0 and 1 (plot)

  • We make σ(z)σ(z) equal to the probability of y=1y=1 or θθ for a Bernoulli distribution.

Example: logistic regression (2)¶

  • Therefore, the likelihood of each observation is as follows

p(yi∣xi,b)=θyii(1−θi)1−yip(yi∣xi,b)=θiyi(1−θi)1−yi

where

θi=σ(xTib)θi=σ(xiTb)

  • Therefore, the likelihood of a set of observations is as follows

p(y1,…,yn,∣b,x1,…,xn)=∏i=1np(yi,∣xi,b)p(y1,…,yn,∣b,x1,…,xn)=∏i=1np(yi,∣xi,b)

Example: logistic regression (3)¶

  • Maximizing the likelihood is similar to what we did for the Gaussian model
  • We will express the negative log-likelihood and minimize it:
    nLL(b)=−log∏i=1np(yi,∣xi,b)=−∑i=1nlog(θyii(1−θi)1−yi)=−∑i=1n(yilogθi+(1−yi)log(1−θi))nLL(b)=−log⁡∏i=1np(yi,∣xi,b)=−∑i=1nlog⁡(θiyi(1−θi)1−yi)=−∑i=1n(yilog⁡θi+(1−yi)log⁡(1−θi))

Example: logistic regression (4)¶

  • Minimizing by finding the parameters that make the derivative 0 cannot be done in one step
  • This does not have a closs solution for logistic regression:
    ∇nLL(b)=0∇nLL(b)=0

Example: logistic regression (5)¶

  • We have to do gradient descent where we perform the following operations several times
    bt+1←bt−λ∇nLL(b)bt+1←bt−λ∇nLL(b)

∇nLL(b)=(dnLL(b)db0…dnLL(b)dbm)∇nLL(b)=(dnLL(b)db0…dnLL(b)dbm)

  • xjxj: the value of feature jj

Logistic regression: What can we do with our model?¶

  • Interpretation is difficult:
    p(y=1|x,b)=σ(b0+∑j=1mbjxj)p(y=1|x,b)=σ(b0+∑j=1mbjxj)
  • How can we interpret bjbj?
  • For example, suppose we can predict whether a customer buys a product based on its price in dollars:
    p(customer buys|price)=σ(0.2−12price)p(customer buys|price)=σ(0.2−12price)
  • How to interpret the weight of price?

Logistic regression: What can we do with our model? (2)¶

  • One typical solution is to look at the probability changes around the 50% threshold (z=0z=0)
    d=p(y=1|x=0 but xj=1)−12d=p(y=1|x=0 but xj=1)−12

Logistic regression: What can we do with our model? (3)¶

  • This expression dd however is still difficult, but we can do a first order approximation around z=0z=0

d≈ddxjσ(z)=σ(z)(1−σ(z))bj=σ(0)(1−σ(0))bj[z=0]=14bjd≈ddxjσ(z)=σ(z)(1−σ(z))bj=σ(0)(1−σ(0))bj[z=0]=14bj

  • Interpret: p(customer buys|price)=σ(0.2−12price)p(customer buys|price)=σ(0.2−12price)

Accuracy vs. interpretability tradeoff¶

In general:

  • Simple models are less accurate but more interpretable.
  • Complex models are more accurate but less interpretable.

Supervised vs unsupervised learning¶

  • Supervised:

    • Each XX is associated with a YY.

  • Unsupervised:

    • We have XX but no association.

  • Supervised learning is in general easier because we know how well we are building the association.

  • Unsupervised learning is harder because there is no clear evaluation method.

  • This course will mostly deal with supervised learning.

Unsupervised learning¶

  • There is no output.
  • It can be seen as learning a function that maps the input into an intermediate representation.
  • That intermediate representation makes the data easier to interpret.
  • There should be a map back from such intermediate representation and the original space.
  • The map from intermediate to feature space (gg) should be as close as possible to the original input.

Examples of unsupervised learning¶

  • Clustering: cluster the diabetic patients into groups.
  • Topic modeling: describe the content of a set of documents (e.g., tweets) based on topics (soft clustering.)
  • Dimensionality reduction: describe a large set of features into a smaller set of features while retaining the variability of the data.

Take-home message¶

  1. Statistical learning acknowledges uncertainty and tries to learn a stochastic model of the data.

  2. We need to define a model of the data.

  3. We need to estimate the parameters of such model.

  4. We can use that model to predict or interpret the results.

  5. We can use supervised learning to learn a relationship between variables.

  6. If variables are not quantitative, we use classification models.
